The Act titled "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for increased disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, and software for filing reports. It also addresses soft money of national political parties and contribution limits. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for increased disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, and software for filing reports. It also addresses limits on soft money of national political party committees, contribution limits, and miscellaneous provisions such as the prohibition of solicitation of political party soft money in Federal buildings and updates of penalty amounts. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require additional monthly reports from principal campaign committees, with exceptions for November and December. A year-end report must be filed by January 31 of the following year. The Act requires monthly reports from campaign committees, excluding November and December. A year-end report is due by January 31 of the following year. Quarterly reports must be filed by the 15th day after each calendar quarter. The treasurer must file quarterly reports by the 15th day after each calendar quarter, with the report for the quarter ending December 31 due by January 31 of the following year. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national committees of political parties to file monthly reports instead of quarterly reports. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require monthly reports instead of quarterly reports for national committees of political parties. SEC. 102. REPORTING BY NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national and congressional political committees to report all receipts and disbursements exceeding $200 for any calendar year. Political committees must itemize receipts and disbursements exceeding $200 from any person in the same manner as required in subsection (b) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Reports must be filed for the same time periods as political committees under subsection (a). SEC. 103 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require the Commission to make reports available on the Internet within 24 hours of receiving the information. SEC. 104 mandates public access to broadcasting records. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require licensees to maintain and make available for public inspection a complete record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 now requires licensees to keep a record of requests to buy broadcast time for political matters of national importance, including messages about qualified candidates and national legislative issues. The record must include whether the request was accepted or rejected. The record maintained under Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 includes information on whether broadcast time requests are accepted or rejected, the rate charged, date and time of airing, class of time purchased, and candidate details for political communications. The record maintained under Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 includes information on broadcast time requests, rates charged, date and time of airing, class of time purchased, and candidate details for political communications. The information required for political communications includes details about the candidate, the authorized committee, the treasurer, and the person purchasing the time. This information must be placed in a political file as required by Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934. The information required for political communications must be placed in a political file by the licensee and retained for at least 2 years. SEC. 105. SOFTWARE FOR FILING OF REPORTS. Section 304(a) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include the development and provision of software for filing reports at no cost to individuals required to file under the Act. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to provide software for filing reports at no cost to individuals required to file under the Act. The software must be used by those maintaining or filing such reports. SEC. 201 of Title II limits soft money of national political party committees under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. SEC. 201 of Title II limits donations to national political party committees to $60,000 per person per calendar year. SEC. 201 of Title II limits donations to national political party committees to $60,000 per person per calendar year, with an aggregate limit on donors not exceeding $60,000 in disbursements in any calendar year. Amounts are adjusted annually based on the price index determined under section 315(c) after 2001. The donation limits to national political party committees are set at $60,000 per person per calendar year, with adjustments based on the price index determined under section 315(c) starting from calendar year 2001. Each increased amount remains in effect for the respective calendar year. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Expedited Review: Members of Congress, candidates, political party committees, or affected individuals can challenge the constitutionality of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. Appeals can be made to the Supreme Court for injunctions or final decisions. (b) Appeal to Supreme Court.--Any order of the US District Court for the District of Columbia regarding an action under subsection (a) can be appealed directly to the Supreme Court. The appeal must be filed within 10 days of the order, with a jurisdictional statement due within 30 days. (c) Expedited Consideration.--Both the District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court must expedite consideration of such appeals. The District Court and Supreme Court must expedite the disposition of appeals under subsection (a). Enforcement of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is stayed during the legal proceedings. Enforcement of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is stayed from the filing of an action under subsection (a) until the Supreme Court's final decision. This provision applies to actions filed within 30 days of the Act's effective date. SEC. 203. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. Increase in contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, with individual and political committee limits raised significantly. Individual limits increased from $1,000 to $3,000, $20,000 to $60,000 for political committees, and $5,000 to $15,000 for other committees. Additionally, the overall contribution limit was raised from $25,000 to $75,000. The contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 have been increased. Individual limits have been raised to $3,000, political committee limits to $60,000, and other committee limits to $15,000. The overall contribution limit has been increased to $75,000. The contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 have been increased. Individual limits are now $3,000, political committee limits are $60,000, and other committee limits are $15,000. The overall contribution limit is now $75,000. Additionally, there are specific exceptions and adjustments made to the limits for national committees of political parties and candidates for Federal office. The overall contribution limit is now $75,000. Specific exceptions and adjustments have been made for national committees of political parties and candidates for Federal office. The overall contribution limit is now $75,000. Specific exceptions and adjustments have been made for national committees of political parties and candidates for Federal office. In any calendar year after 2002, limitations established by subsections (a), (b), (d), or (h) shall be increased by a certain percentage and remain in effect for that year. The contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 have been increased. Limits for individuals, political committees, and other committees have been raised. The overall contribution limit is now $75,000. Specific adjustments have been made for national committees and candidates for Federal office. Limitations established by subsections (a), (b), (d), or (h) will be increased by a certain percentage and remain in effect for the calendar year. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 has increased contribution limits. For Senate candidates, the limit for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees has been raised from $17,500 to $60,000. Effective dates for these amendments have been specified. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 has raised contribution limits for Senate candidates, increasing the limit for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees from $17,500 to $60,000. The amendments will apply to calendar years beginning after December 31, 2001, with specific provisions for calendar years after December 31, 2002. TITLE III--MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

SEC. 301. PROHIBITION OF SOLICITATION OF POLITICAL PARTY SOFT MONEY IN FEDERAL BUILDINGS. Section 607 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to define "contribution" as a gift, subscription, loan, advance, or deposit of money or anything of value made in connection with elections for Federal office or political committees. The curr_chunk states that money or anything of value made in connection with elections for Federal office, political committees, or political parties is prohibited. Additionally, Section 602(a)(4) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include this prohibition. SEC. 302. UPDATE OF PENALTY AMOUNTS. Section 309 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to adjust dollar amounts for inflation after 2001 based on the price index. This adjustment does not apply to amounts under subsection (d) other than the $25,000 amount. SEC. 303. Filing of Senate reports with the Federal Election Commission. Section 302 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to specify that all required filings must be submitted to the Commission. Additionally, Title III of the Act is amended to include the Commission and Secretary of State in certain subsections. In section 304, subsection (a)(6)(A) is amended to include the "Commission and Secretary of State." Subsection (c)(2) is also amended to remove "the Secretary or." Section 311(a)(4) is amended to remove "Secretary or the."
